taskDescription: A student finds the number of edges in a complete graph by taking half the number of vertices, then subtracting one from the number of vertices, then multiplying these two values together. Will the student get the correct result?
detailedSolution: Yes. If n is the number of vertices in a complete graph, the number of edges is n ( n − 1 ) 2 = n 2 ( n − 1 ) \frac{{n(n - 1)}}{2} = \frac{n}{2}(n - 1) which is half the number of vertices times one less than the number of vertices.
